qas.question: What's the Dutch word for "seahorse" that has no non-diminutive form?
What Dutch word did their word for "girl" come from that has a totally different meaning?
What's the Dutch word for the items like shirts and pants that you wear that only exists in a plural form?
Sometimes uncountable nouns in Dutch get a diminutive ending to make them refer to what, like an ice cream cone?

context: Some nouns have two different diminutives, each with a different meaning: bloem (flower) → bloempje (lit. "small flower"), but <a0_0>bloemetje<a0_0/> (lit. also "small flower", meaning bouquet). A few nouns exist solely in a diminutive form, e.g. <a1_0>zeepaardje<a1_0/> (seahorse), while many, e.g. meisje (girl), originally a diminutive of <a2_0>meid<a2_0/> (maid), have acquired a meaning independent of their non-diminutive forms. A diminutive can sometimes be added to an uncountable noun to refer to <a4_0>a single portion<a4_0/>: ijs (ice, ice cream) → ijsje (ice cream treat, cone of ice cream), bier (beer) → biertje. Some diminutive forms only exist in plural, e.g. <a3_0>kleertjes<a3_0/> (clothing).
